output.conclusion: This course has provided an advanced overview of key biochemical principles. Further study is encouraged to delve deeper into specific areas of interest.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Biochemistry! This course builds upon foundational knowledge to explore complex biochemical pathways and regulatory mechanisms.

chapters.description: Explore the forces driving protein folding, including hydrophobic interactions and disulfide bonds. Discuss methods for predicting protein structure and the role of chaperones.
Delve into advanced enzyme kinetics, including multi-substrate reactions and allosteric regulation. Examine detailed mechanisms of enzyme catalysis, focusing on specific examples.
Discuss the regulation of glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, and the pentose phosphate pathway. Analyze the metabolic fates of pyruvate and the role of the citric acid cycle.
Explore fatty acid synthesis and degradation, including the role of acetyl-CoA carboxylase and carnitine shuttle. Discuss the metabolism of cholesterol and lipoproteins.
Examine the mechanisms of DNA replication, including the role of DNA polymerases and other replication factors. Discuss various DNA repair pathways and their significance.
Explore the regulation of gene transcription in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Analyze the processes of RNA splicing, capping, and polyadenylation.
Discuss the mechanisms of receptor-mediated signaling, including G protein-coupled receptors and receptor tyrosine kinases. Analyze downstream signaling pathways, such as MAPK and PI3K.
Explore the role of hormones in regulating metabolism and gene expression. Discuss the mechanisms of hormone action, including steroid hormone receptors and peptide hormone signaling.
Examine the structure and function of antibodies and T cell receptors. Discuss the mechanisms of antigen recognition and the activation of the immune response.
Explore the biochemical mechanisms underlying various diseases, including genetic disorders, metabolic diseases, and cancer. Discuss the role of biochemistry in drug discovery and development.
